trans-unit.source: Authoring Azure Resource Manager Templates
trans-unit.target: Authoring Azure Resource Manager Templates

trans-unit.source: Create Azure Resource Manager templates using declarative JSON syntax to deploy applications to Azure.
trans-unit.target: Create Azure Resource Manager templates using declarative JSON syntax to deploy applications to Azure.

trans-unit.source: Authoring Azure Resource Manager templates
trans-unit.target: Authoring Azure Resource Manager templates

trans-unit.source: Azure applications typically require a combination of resources (such as a database server, database, or website) to meet the desired goals.
trans-unit.target: Azure applications typically require a combination of resources (such as a database server, database, or website) to meet the desired goals.

trans-unit.source: Rather than deploying and managing each resource separately, you can create an Azure Resource Manager template that deploys and provisions all of the resources for your application in a single, coordinated operation.
trans-unit.target: Rather than deploying and managing each resource separately, you can create an Azure Resource Manager template that deploys and provisions all of the resources for your application in a single, coordinated operation.

trans-unit.source: In the template, you define the resources that are needed for the application and specify deployment parameters to input values for different environments.
trans-unit.target: In the template, you define the resources that are needed for the application and specify deployment parameters to input values for different environments.

trans-unit.source: The template consists of JSON and expressions which you can use to construct values for your deployment.
trans-unit.target: The template consists of JSON and expressions which you can use to construct values for your deployment.

trans-unit.source: This topic describes the sections of the template.
trans-unit.target: This topic describes the sections of the template.

trans-unit.source: For the actual schemas, see [Azure Resource Manager Schemas](https://github.com/Azure/azure-resource-manager-schemas).
trans-unit.target: For the actual schemas, see [Azure Resource Manager Schemas](https://github.com/Azure/azure-resource-manager-schemas).

trans-unit.source: You must limit the size your template to 1 MB, and each parameter file to 64 KB.
trans-unit.target: You must limit the size your template to 1 MB, and each parameter file to 64 KB.

trans-unit.source: The 1 MB limit applies to the final state of the template after it has been expanded with iterative resource definitions, and values for variables and parameters.
trans-unit.target: The 1 MB limit applies to the final state of the template after it has been expanded with iterative resource definitions, and values for variables and parameters.

trans-unit.source: Template format
trans-unit.target: Template format

trans-unit.source: The following example shows the sections that make up the basic structure of a template.
trans-unit.target: The following example shows the sections that make up the basic structure of a template.

trans-unit.source: Element name
trans-unit.target: Element name

trans-unit.source: Required
trans-unit.target: Required

trans-unit.source: Description
trans-unit.target: Description

trans-unit.source: $schema
trans-unit.target: $schema

trans-unit.source: Yes
trans-unit.target: Yes

trans-unit.source: Location of the JSON schema file that describes the version of the template language.
trans-unit.target: Location of the JSON schema file that describes the version of the template language.

trans-unit.source: contentVersion
trans-unit.target: contentVersion

trans-unit.source: Yes
trans-unit.target: Yes

trans-unit.source: Version of the template (such as 1.0.0.0).
trans-unit.target: Version of the template (such as 1.0.0.0).

trans-unit.source: When deploying resources using the template, this value can be used to make sure that the right template is being used.
trans-unit.target: When deploying resources using the template, this value can be used to make sure that the right template is being used.

trans-unit.source: parameters
trans-unit.target: parameters

trans-unit.source: No
trans-unit.target: No

trans-unit.source: Values that are provided when deployment is executed to customize resource deployment.
trans-unit.target: Values that are provided when deployment is executed to customize resource deployment.

trans-unit.source: variables
trans-unit.target: variables

trans-unit.source: No
trans-unit.target: No

trans-unit.source: Values that are used as JSON fragments in the template to simplify template language expressions.
trans-unit.target: Values that are used as JSON fragments in the template to simplify template language expressions.

trans-unit.source: resources
trans-unit.target: resources

trans-unit.source: Yes
trans-unit.target: Yes

trans-unit.source: Types of services that are deployed or updated in a resource group.
trans-unit.target: Types of services that are deployed or updated in a resource group.

trans-unit.source: outputs
trans-unit.target: outputs

trans-unit.source: No
trans-unit.target: No

trans-unit.source: Values that are returned after deployment.
trans-unit.target: Values that are returned after deployment.

trans-unit.source: We will examine the sections of the template in greater detail later in this topic.
trans-unit.target: We will examine the sections of the template in greater detail later in this topic.

trans-unit.source: For now, we will review some of the syntax that makes up the template.
trans-unit.target: For now, we will review some of the syntax that makes up the template.

trans-unit.source: Expressions and functions
trans-unit.target: Expressions and functions

trans-unit.source: The basic syntax of the template is JSON; however, expressions and functions extend the JSON that is available in the template and enable you to create values that are not strict literal values.
trans-unit.target: The basic syntax of the template is JSON; however, expressions and functions extend the JSON that is available in the template and enable you to create values that are not strict literal values.

trans-unit.source: Expressions are enclosed with brackets ([ and ]), and are evaluated when the template is deployed.
trans-unit.target: Expressions are enclosed with brackets ([ and ]), and are evaluated when the template is deployed.

trans-unit.source: Expressions can appear anywhere in a JSON string value and always return another JSON value.
trans-unit.target: Expressions can appear anywhere in a JSON string value and always return another JSON value.

trans-unit.source: If you need to use a literal string that starts with a bracket [, you must use two brackets [[.
trans-unit.target: If you need to use a literal string that starts with a bracket [, you must use two brackets [[.

trans-unit.source: Typically, you use expressions with functions to perform operations for configuring the deployment.
trans-unit.target: Typically, you use expressions with functions to perform operations for configuring the deployment.

trans-unit.source: Just like in JavaScript, function calls are formatted as **functionName(arg1,arg2,arg3)**.
trans-unit.target: Just like in JavaScript, function calls are formatted as **functionName(arg1,arg2,arg3)**.

trans-unit.source: You reference properties by using the dot and [index] operators.
trans-unit.target: You reference properties by using the dot and [index] operators.

trans-unit.source: The following list shows common functions.
trans-unit.target: The following list shows common functions.

trans-unit.source: parameters(parameterName)
trans-unit.target: parameters(parameterName)

trans-unit.source: Returns a parameter value that is provided when the deployment is executed.
trans-unit.target: Returns a parameter value that is provided when the deployment is executed.

trans-unit.source: variables(variableName)
trans-unit.target: variables(variableName)

trans-unit.source: Returns a variable that is defined in the template.
trans-unit.target: Returns a variable that is defined in the template.

trans-unit.source: concat(arg1,arg2,arg3,...)
trans-unit.target: concat(arg1,arg2,arg3,...)

trans-unit.source: Combines multiple string values.
trans-unit.target: Combines multiple string values.

trans-unit.source: This function can take any number of arguments.
trans-unit.target: This function can take any number of arguments.

trans-unit.source: base64(inputString)
trans-unit.target: base64(inputString)

trans-unit.source: Returns the base64 representation of the input string.
trans-unit.target: Returns the base64 representation of the input string.

trans-unit.source: resourceGroup()
trans-unit.target: resourceGroup()

trans-unit.source: Returns a structured object (with id, name, and location properties) that represents the current resource group.
trans-unit.target: Returns a structured object (with id, name, and location properties) that represents the current resource group.

trans-unit.source: resourceId([resourceGroupName], resourceType, resourceName1, [resourceName2]...)
trans-unit.target: resourceId([resourceGroupName], resourceType, resourceName1, [resourceName2]...)

trans-unit.source: Returns the unique identifier of a resource.
trans-unit.target: Returns the unique identifier of a resource.

trans-unit.source: Can be used to retrieve resource from another resource group.
trans-unit.target: Can be used to retrieve resource from another resource group.

trans-unit.source: The following example shows how to use several of the functions when constructing values:
trans-unit.target: The following example shows how to use several of the functions when constructing values:

trans-unit.source: For now, you know enough about expressions and functions to understand the sections of the template.
trans-unit.target: For now, you know enough about expressions and functions to understand the sections of the template.

trans-unit.source: For more detailed information about all of the template functions, including parameters and the format of returned values,
trans-unit.target: For more detailed information about all of the template functions, including parameters and the format of returned values,

trans-unit.source: see [Azure Resource Manager template functions](./resource-group-template-functions.md).
trans-unit.target: see [Azure Resource Manager template functions](./resource-group-template-functions.md).

trans-unit.source: Parameters
trans-unit.target: Parameters

trans-unit.source: In the parameters section of the template, you specify which values a user can input when deploying the resources.
trans-unit.target: In the parameters section of the template, you specify which values a user can input when deploying the resources.

trans-unit.source: You can use these parameter values throughout the template to set values for the deployed resources.
trans-unit.target: You can use these parameter values throughout the template to set values for the deployed resources.

trans-unit.source: Only parameters that are declared in the parameters section can be used in other sections of the template.
trans-unit.target: Only parameters that are declared in the parameters section can be used in other sections of the template.

trans-unit.source: Within parameters section, you cannot use a parameter value to construct another parameter value.
trans-unit.target: Within parameters section, you cannot use a parameter value to construct another parameter value.

trans-unit.source: That type of operation typically happens in the variables section.
trans-unit.target: That type of operation typically happens in the variables section.

trans-unit.source: You define parameters with the following structure:
trans-unit.target: You define parameters with the following structure:

trans-unit.source: Element name
trans-unit.target: Element name

trans-unit.source: Required
trans-unit.target: Required

trans-unit.source: Description
trans-unit.target: Description

trans-unit.source: parameterName
trans-unit.target: parameterName

trans-unit.source: Yes
trans-unit.target: Yes

trans-unit.source: Name of the parameter.
trans-unit.target: Name of the parameter.

trans-unit.source: Must be a valid JavaScript identifier.
trans-unit.target: Must be a valid JavaScript identifier.

trans-unit.source: type
trans-unit.target: type

trans-unit.source: Yes
trans-unit.target: Yes

trans-unit.source: Type of the parameter value.
trans-unit.target: Type of the parameter value.

trans-unit.source: See the list below of allowed types.
trans-unit.target: See the list below of allowed types.

trans-unit.source: defaultValue
trans-unit.target: defaultValue

trans-unit.source: No
trans-unit.target: No

trans-unit.source: Default value for the parameter, if no value is provided for the parameter.
trans-unit.target: Default value for the parameter, if no value is provided for the parameter.

trans-unit.source: allowedValues
trans-unit.target: allowedValues

trans-unit.source: No
trans-unit.target: No

trans-unit.source: Array of allowed values for the parameter to make sure that the right value is provided.
trans-unit.target: Array of allowed values for the parameter to make sure that the right value is provided.

trans-unit.source: The allowed types and values are:
trans-unit.target: The allowed types and values are:

trans-unit.source: string or secureString - any valid JSON string
trans-unit.target: string or secureString - any valid JSON string

trans-unit.source: int - any valid JSON integer
trans-unit.target: int - any valid JSON integer

trans-unit.source: bool - any valid JSON boolean
trans-unit.target: bool - any valid JSON boolean

trans-unit.source: object or secureObject - any valid JSON object
trans-unit.target: object or secureObject - any valid JSON object

trans-unit.source: array - any valid JSON array
trans-unit.target: array - any valid JSON array

trans-unit.source: [AZURE.NOTE] All passwords, keys, and other secrets should use the **secureString** type.
trans-unit.target: [AZURE.NOTE] All passwords, keys, and other secrets should use the **secureString** type.

trans-unit.source: Template parameters with the secureString type cannot be read after resource deployment.
trans-unit.target: Template parameters with the secureString type cannot be read after resource deployment.

trans-unit.source: The following example shows how to define parameters:
trans-unit.target: The following example shows how to define parameters:

trans-unit.source: Variables
trans-unit.target: Variables

trans-unit.source: In the variables section, you construct values that can be used to simplify template language expressions.
trans-unit.target: In the variables section, you construct values that can be used to simplify template language expressions.

trans-unit.source: Typically, these variables will be based on values provided from the parameters.
trans-unit.target: Typically, these variables will be based on values provided from the parameters.

trans-unit.source: The following example shows how to define a variable that is constructed from two parameter values:
trans-unit.target: The following example shows how to define a variable that is constructed from two parameter values:

trans-unit.source: The next example shows a variable that is a complex JSON type, and variables that are constructed from other variables:
trans-unit.target: The next example shows a variable that is a complex JSON type, and variables that are constructed from other variables:

trans-unit.source: Resources
trans-unit.target: Resources

trans-unit.source: In the resources section, you define the resources are deployed or updated.
trans-unit.target: In the resources section, you define the resources are deployed or updated.

trans-unit.source: You define resources with the following structure:
trans-unit.target: You define resources with the following structure:

trans-unit.source: Element name
trans-unit.target: Element name

trans-unit.source: Required
trans-unit.target: Required

trans-unit.source: Description
trans-unit.target: Description

trans-unit.source: apiVersion
trans-unit.target: apiVersion

trans-unit.source: Yes
trans-unit.target: Yes

trans-unit.source: Version of the API that supports the resource.
trans-unit.target: Version of the API that supports the resource.

trans-unit.source: For the available versions and schemas for resources, see [Azure Resource Manager Schemas](https://github.com/Azure/azure-resource-manager-schemas).
trans-unit.target: For the available versions and schemas for resources, see [Azure Resource Manager Schemas](https://github.com/Azure/azure-resource-manager-schemas).

trans-unit.source: type
trans-unit.target: type

trans-unit.source: Yes
trans-unit.target: Yes

trans-unit.source: Type of the resource.
trans-unit.target: Type of the resource.

trans-unit.source: This value is a combination of the namespace of the resource provider and the resource type that the resource provider supports.
trans-unit.target: This value is a combination of the namespace of the resource provider and the resource type that the resource provider supports.

trans-unit.source: name
trans-unit.target: name

trans-unit.source: Yes
trans-unit.target: Yes

trans-unit.source: Name of the resource.
trans-unit.target: Name of the resource.

trans-unit.source: The name must follow URI component restrictions defined in RFC3986.
trans-unit.target: The name must follow URI component restrictions defined in RFC3986.

trans-unit.source: location
trans-unit.target: location

trans-unit.source: No
trans-unit.target: No

trans-unit.source: Supported geo-locations of the provided resource.
trans-unit.target: Supported geo-locations of the provided resource.

trans-unit.source: tags
trans-unit.target: tags

trans-unit.source: No
trans-unit.target: No

trans-unit.source: Tags that are associated with the resource.
trans-unit.target: Tags that are associated with the resource.

trans-unit.source: dependsOn
trans-unit.target: dependsOn

trans-unit.source: No
trans-unit.target: No

trans-unit.source: Resources that the resource being defined depends on.
trans-unit.target: Resources that the resource being defined depends on.

trans-unit.source: The dependencies between resources are evaluated and resources are deployed in their dependent order.
trans-unit.target: The dependencies between resources are evaluated and resources are deployed in their dependent order.

trans-unit.source: When resources are not dependent on each other, they are attempted to be deployed in parallel.
trans-unit.target: When resources are not dependent on each other, they are attempted to be deployed in parallel.

trans-unit.source: The value can be a comma separated list of a resource names or resource unique identifiers.
trans-unit.target: The value can be a comma separated list of a resource names or resource unique identifiers.

trans-unit.source: properties
trans-unit.target: properties

trans-unit.source: No
trans-unit.target: No

trans-unit.source: Resource specific configuration settings.
trans-unit.target: Resource specific configuration settings.

trans-unit.source: resources
trans-unit.target: resources

trans-unit.source: No
trans-unit.target: No

trans-unit.source: Child resources that depend on the resource being defined.
trans-unit.target: Child resources that depend on the resource being defined.

trans-unit.source: If the resource name is not unique, you can use the **resourceId** helper function (described below) to get the unique identifier for any resource.
trans-unit.target: If the resource name is not unique, you can use the **resourceId** helper function (described below) to get the unique identifier for any resource.

trans-unit.source: Outputs
trans-unit.target: Outputs

trans-unit.source: In the Outputs section, you specify values that are returned from deployment.
trans-unit.target: In the Outputs section, you specify values that are returned from deployment.

trans-unit.source: For example, you could return the URI to access a deployed resource.
trans-unit.target: For example, you could return the URI to access a deployed resource.

trans-unit.source: The following example shows the structure of an output definition:
trans-unit.target: The following example shows the structure of an output definition:

trans-unit.source: Element name
trans-unit.target: Element name

trans-unit.source: Required
trans-unit.target: Required

trans-unit.source: Description
trans-unit.target: Description

trans-unit.source: outputName
trans-unit.target: outputName

trans-unit.source: Yes
trans-unit.target: Yes

trans-unit.source: Name of the output value.
trans-unit.target: Name of the output value.

trans-unit.source: Must be a valid JavaScript identifier.
trans-unit.target: Must be a valid JavaScript identifier.

trans-unit.source: type
trans-unit.target: type

trans-unit.source: Yes
trans-unit.target: Yes

trans-unit.source: Type of the output value.
trans-unit.target: Type of the output value.

trans-unit.source: Output values support the same types as template input parameters.
trans-unit.target: Output values support the same types as template input parameters.

trans-unit.source: value
trans-unit.target: value

trans-unit.source: Yes
trans-unit.target: Yes

trans-unit.source: Template language expression which will be evaluated and returned as output value.
trans-unit.target: Template language expression which will be evaluated and returned as output value.

trans-unit.source: More advanced scenarios.
trans-unit.target: More advanced scenarios.

trans-unit.source: This topic provides an introductory look at the template.
trans-unit.target: This topic provides an introductory look at the template.

trans-unit.source: However, your scenario may require more advanced tasks.
trans-unit.target: However, your scenario may require more advanced tasks.

trans-unit.source: You may need to merge two templates together or use a child template within a parent template.
trans-unit.target: You may need to merge two templates together or use a child template within a parent template.

trans-unit.source: For more information, see [Using linked templates with Azure Resource Manager](resource-group-linked-templates.md).
trans-unit.target: For more information, see [Using linked templates with Azure Resource Manager](resource-group-linked-templates.md).

trans-unit.source: To iterate a specified number of times when creating a type of resource, see [Create multiple instances of resources in Azure Resource Manager](resource-group-create-multiple.md).
trans-unit.target: To iterate a specified number of times when creating a type of resource, see [Create multiple instances of resources in Azure Resource Manager](resource-group-create-multiple.md).

trans-unit.source: You may need to use resources that exist within a different resource group.
trans-unit.target: You may need to use resources that exist within a different resource group.

trans-unit.source: This is common when working with storage accounts or virtual networks that are shared across multiple resource groups.
trans-unit.target: This is common when working with storage accounts or virtual networks that are shared across multiple resource groups.

trans-unit.source: For more information, see the [resourceId function](../resource-group-template-functions#resourceid).
trans-unit.target: For more information, see the [resourceId function](../resource-group-template-functions#resourceid).
